title: How similar are Cantonese and Hakka? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not too much. My ex is Hakka and her parents are also Hakka. The Hakka dialect that her hometown speaks (in Renhua County, near Shaoguan), is different from the dialect her parents speak. Matter of fact, her parents come from different villages, and their villages speak different dialects from each other. Her mom speaks her village speak, her dad speaks his village speak, and she understands both, but speaks the hometown one. Most people in her hometown can understand her parents’ speak, but when they go to Shaoguan they speak a “more standard” Hakka dialect, than their village speak. When they go to Guangzhou and speak Hakka, people won’t understand them, unless they are Hakka, too. Chiuchow people who speak Cantonese but never learned Hakka (or never spent time around Hakka people) probably won’t understand Hakka. Once upon a time she was answering a call from her mom and I was standing next to her. She was giving her mom the new phone number of her cousin and she was speaking the numbers one by one. I know how to count in Cantonese and didn’t understand jack shit, until she told me what she was doing.  Long, long time ago, I had a lecture about Chinese languages by a very respected linguist back home. He was of the opinion (that was in early 2000s), that when talking about languages in China, and the ability of speakers of said languages to communicate with each other, it is actually more correct to say that there are over 6,000 languages, most of which come with dozens of local dialects. For him, Mandarin, Cantonese, Hakka or Chiuchow should actually be considered separate languages, rather than just dialects of “Chinese,” because if one considered Hakka or Cantonese a “dialect,” one should also consider Polish and Russian dialects - that’s how far these languages are from each other.

Quite similar 。My mum's mum is Hakka，and although her dad isn't Hakka (he is Hubei)，her entire immediate family all speaks East Malaysian Hakka just for the sake of communication 。My dad is from Hong Kong and my mum's family all speaks Cantonese (since it's such a big and influential language across Asia)，so growing up I didn't have the need to learn Hakka since everyone spoke Cantonese and so I never learnt Hakka 。When we were in Miri to visit my family，my Mum's family would all converse in Hakka and I'd say I could understand around 30–35% of what they were saying，based on my limited Hakka knowledge 。They have a lot of similar vocab and phrases，just the pronunciation is often a bit different and the final stop constants are sometimes changed 。Honestly not too different，but then again it depends on the variety of Hakka you speak; I'd probably understand up to 10% of a Taiwanese Hakka 。The Hakka community in Hong Kong is also quite large 。But yeah，the two languages have many differences and similarities，and it's really beautiful and I hope that by learning them I can help preserve their usage and thousands of years of history 。
